questions.question: Question 1: In patients with sarcoidosis, which of the following is the most commonly affected organ?
questions.explanation:
Sarcoidosis most commonly affects the lungs. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. It 
commonly involves the lungs, skin, liver, and eyes.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 35-year-old woman with history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the 
image below. Identify the condition.
questions.explanation:
The given condition is lupus pernio which is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis. Lupus pernio is a chronic inflammatory skin lesion, which is diagnostic for a chronic form of 
sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks and often 
is purple in color. Other options: 505 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Acne rosacea is a skin disorder with onset in middle■aged adults (30–50 years old) and 
involves the convexities of the face. Option C: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in 
dermatomyositis. Option D: Malar rash or butterfly rash is classically seen in SLE.

questions.question:
Question 3: 500 
Sold by @itachibot A 24-year-old man presented with fever, productive cough, and weight loss. On examination, 
the following skin lesions were seen. His chest X-ray showed hilar lymphadenopathy. Which 
is the next best investigation for the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features along with examination findings of lupus vulgaris is suggestive 
of tuberculosis. The next best investigation is AFB smear microscopy of the sputum sample. Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis. It has a characteristic slow enlarging 
plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy.

questions.question:
Question 4: A man came to the clinic with fatigue, cough, and breathing difficulty. His chest X-ray showed 
bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and lung biopsy revealed non-caseating granuloma. What is 
the most common ocular manifestation associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features along with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and non-caseating 
granuloma are suggestive of sarcoidosis. The most common ocular manifestation in sarcoidosis is 
anterior uveitis. Anterior uveitis presents with photophobia, blurry vision, and lacrimation. Other ocular 
manifestations include retinitis, pars planitis, and dry eyes.

questions.question: Question 5: Which is the most common cranial nerve to be involved in sarcoidosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cranial nerve to be involved in sarcoidosis is the facial nerve leading to facial 
palsy. Neurosarcoidosis frequently manifests as follows: • Cranial nerve involvement- optic neuritis (CN II), extraocular muscles involvement (CN III, IV, 
VI) and facial palsy (CN VII) • Space occupying lesions • Diabetes insipidus - due to anterior hypothalamus involvement • Basilar meningitis

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following features would you not expect in a patient diagnosed with Lofgren’s 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Parotid enlargement is not a feature of Lofgren's syndrome. Lofgren’s syndrome is an acute form 
of sarcoidosis that has a good prognosis, with most of the patients experiencing disease resolution 
within 2 years. 506 
Sold by @itachibot It is characterized by: • Arthritis • Erythema nodosum • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy Heerfordt–Waldenström syndrome also known as uveoparotid fever is a variant of sarcoidosis 
characterized by: • Fever • Parotid enlargement • Facial palsy • Anterior uveitis

questions.question:
Question 7: A 44-year-old construction worker, who is a known case of sarcoidosis, has now presented 
with polyuria, constipation, and myalgia for the past 5 days. An ECG was taken which showed 
a short QT interval. Which of the following is responsible for this 
condition?■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■       ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■ 
■■■■■■■■■■

options.d: Increased production of PTH related peptide

questions.explanation:
The given clinical features along with a short QT interval points towards hypercalcemia. 
Hypercalcemia in a patient with sarcoidosis is due to the increased production of vitamin D by the 
non-caseating granulomas. Hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria are seen in some patients with sarcoidosis. The increased 
production of vitamin D (1,25-dihydoxyvitamin D) results in increased intestinal absorption of 
calcium, leading to hypercalcemia. Vitamin D supplementation and increased sun exposure in patients with sarcoidosis can 
precipitate hypercalcemia.

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient was evaluated for unexplained cough and shortness of breath. Investigations 
revealed elevated serum calcium and a chest X-ray showed hilar lymphadenopathy. A lymph 
node biopsy was taken to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is least likely to be 
seen in the histopathological examination?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoidosis, in which the histopathological examination 
of lesions does not show Masson bodies. Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing 
connective tissue seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia. The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the 
non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas: • Schaumann bodies- inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification • Asteroid bodies- stellate inclusions in the giant cells

questions.question: Question 9: What is the most common abnormality of liver function in sarcoidosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common abnormality of liver function in sarcoidosis is the elevation of alkaline 
phosphatase (ALP) levels. 507 
Sold by @itachibot Sarcoidosis of the liver presents as a granulomatous disease that causes intrahepatic cholestasis. 
As the disease advances it leads to elevated liver enzymes followed by elevated bilirubin levels.

questions.question:
Question 10: A middle-aged woman presented to you with shortness of breath and dry cough for the past 3 
months. On examination, the following skin lesions were seen. You will order all of the 
following investigations except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings of erythema nodosum are suggestive of 
sarcoidosis. CD4/CD8 ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid, not blood, is used for diagnosis 
of sarcoidosis. Erythema nodosum is inflammation of the subcutaneous fat (panniculitis) seen in sarcoidosis. The investigations used in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis include: • Serum ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels - elevated • BAL- lymphocytosis and increased CD4/CD8 ratio. A ratio of >3.5 in BAL is strongly 
supportive of sarcoidosis. • PET-CT scan - to identify areas of granulomatous disease • Gallium scan shows the following signs: • Panda sign- due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis • Lambda sign- due to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes which resembles lambda 
() • Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas in a patient with features of sarcoidosis confirms the

Question 11: 503 
Sold by @itachibot The chest radiograph of a young man with sarcoidosis shows pulmonary infiltrates in the 
upper lobes of his lungs without hilar lymphadenopathy. What is the grade of lung 
involvement according to Scadding scoring system?
questions.explanation:
508 
Sold by @itachibot According to the Scadding scoring system, the presence of pulmonary infiltrates alone represents 
grade III. The Scadding scoring system is used to grade lung involvement in sarcoidosis. It is based on the 
chest radiograph findings: • Grade I: Hilar lymphadenopathy, often with right paratracheal involvement. No pulmonary 
infiltrates. • Grade II: Hilar lymphadenopathy + pulmonary infiltrates • Grade III: Pulmonary infiltrates only • Grade IV: Fibrosis Sarcoidosis predominantly involves the upper lobes of the lungs.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following lymph nodes is not involved in the Garland triad?
questions.explanation:
Garland triad does not involve left paratracheal lymph nodes. Garland triad also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is a lymph node enlargement 
pattern in sarcoidosis that involves: • Right paratracheal nodes (1) • Right hilar nodes (2) • Left hilar nodes (3)

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is the first-line drug for a patient diagnosed with sarcoidosis with 
multiple organ involvement?
questions.explanation:
The first-line drug for sarcoidosis with multiple organ involvement is prednisolone. Management of sarcoidosis: 509 
Sold by @itachibot • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids • Multisystem involvement: • Systemic steroids • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the 
steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following conditions is not associated with a significant elevation of 
angiotensin-converting enzyme levels?
questions.explanation:
Diabetes is associated with a mild elevation of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels. Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in: • Sarcoidosis • Silicosis • Leprosy • Gaucher’s disease • Hyperthyroidism • Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis 510 
Sold by @itachibot Dermatomyositis and Related Disorders
